attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was conducted on 11 March 2025 to validate the accuracy of stock records by comparing the actual inventory levels with the data in the SAP system and to evaluate the effectiveness of existing controls.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following:

Ø  Bread stock had a variance of -48 pieces

Ø  Polybags had +650 pieces

Ø  White flour had -5.212kgs

Ø  Crates had Nil Variations.

Ø  Other raw materials had raw materials had immaterial variations.

·       The table below illustrates the findings:

Table 1:Stock verification.
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should strengthen controls on movement of finished product to minimize the noted variations.

·       The branch should check the route cause of polybags variations and accuracy of good issue sent for polybags.
attributes.effect:
·       Variations noted in bread stock indicates lapses in proper recording of movement of Finished product.

·       Excess positive poly bags variations indicate lapses in proper recording of good issues sent for polybags and Possibility excess packaging of 200 sachets.Nil variations in crates movement indicates crates movement controls is well controlled.

value:
·       Bread stock resulted from wrong posting of 1.5 Kg posting, the short was recovered.

·       Positive variations in polybags are a result of excess packaging especially on 400g CT.
·       Bread stock variation was recovered from branch manager, he has been advised to enforce supervisor handing over shift wise.Crates movements well controlled by regular physical stocks

·       In the prior Audit report dated 8th March 2025, it was noted that:

ü  Bread stock had a variance of -1 loaf

ü  Packing materials had +1259 pieces.

ü  White flour had a deficit of -1 unit

ü  Other raw materials had minimal Variations.
Current

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
·      A spot check on packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market was done on 11 April 2025, to determine if the branch was producing bread of standard weight.

·       Underweights and Over-weights were noted across all bread varieties weighed, however they were minimal and Overall average weights were okey as seen;

Table 2:Bread weight Check.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch should ensure correct standard operating procedures are strictly followed to ensure bread of correct weight is produced.Random spot checks on dough and packed bread should be done by the branch manager on regular basis to ensure bread of correct weight is supplied to the market.
attributes.effect: ·       Selling underweight bread in the market could result in non-compliance with weights and measures regulations, potentially exposing the company to fines and legal action.Supplying underweight products may lead to customer dissatisfaction, harm the brand’s reputation, and potentially result in a loss of customers.

value: Underweights sometimes caused by overcooling but we will do a follow up to ensure correct procedures are followed to ensure bread of correct weight is supplied to the market.
Strict measures have been put to ensure correct weight is achieved and  we will be conducting random spot checks of dough and packed bread.

·       In the prior audit dated 8th March 2025, it was noted that, underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -4%

ü  800 CTW-0%,

ü  400g Long-7%,
Current

attributes.title: Bread damages.
attributes.description:
·       Bread damages analysis was done for a period of 42 days from 1 March 2025 to 11 April 2025 to determine if they were within the allowable threshold of 0.2% of total production for production related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market related damages.

·       The analysis showed that production damages stood at 0.23% which was above the allowable limit with a cost implication of Kshs.8,702.55 while market damages stood at 0.56% which was above the allowable limit 0.5% with a cost implication of Kshs.17,178.80.

·       The summary of the findings is detailed below:

Table 3:Production Damages.

N/B The above analysis is exclusive of 252 pieces of Oven damages.

Table 4:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation: ·       To adhere to the set quality control procedures within the production process to minimize damages.Branch management should ensure production equipment and ovens are regularly maintained.
attributes.effect:
·       Production damages exceeded the allowable limit by 0.03% which resulted to an extra cost of Kshs 8,702.55 while market damages exceeded the limit by 0.06 % which resulted in an extra cost to the company of Kshs 17,178.80.

Excess damages indicates that product quality was not fully met resulting in more damages above allowable limits.

value: ·       The slicing machine was blunt which resulted to deformed bread hence leading excess market damages, but the issue has been resolved.Excess production damages were caused by Oven Gasket which resulted to uneven heat distribution leading to more production damages, but the issue has been resolved and this will be improved.
We had slicer machine problem of spindle, which product resulted in deformity hence leading to excess market damages, but the issue was resolved.

·       During the prior audit report dated 8th March 2025 it was noted that:        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.19% of the production.

ü  Market damages stood at 0.54% of the sales.Damages sent to ingredient department had a variance of -17.35 Kgs equivalent to 43 pieces with a cost implication of Kshs 2,298.87.
Current

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the mixing charts and summaries was conducted for a period of 42 days from 1 March 2025-11 April 2025, to evaluate whether raw material usage was aligned with the established branch BOM and to determine if Branch production capacity was fully met.

·       The analysis showed that

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 191.11 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 68.19 bags per day representing 84.19% of the set target of 81 bags.

ü  There we no cases remixes for the reviewed period.

·       The table below shows a summarised finding of the mixing chart analysis.

Table 5:Mixing Chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management team and sales team should put effort to onboard more customers to ensure idle branch capacity is utilized.
attributes.effect: ·       No remixes is an indication that bread quality was not compromised.Branch production capacity was not fully utilized, idle capacity represents 15.81% of the branch capacity 81 bags, this is equivalent to 2,459.52 loaves, potential daily revenue of= (2459.52*53) Kshs 130,354.56.)

value: We do production as per the market demand /average sales, but we are working on improving so far, we opened kabati Mini shop and a depot in mwingi we are waiting for another depot in Garissa which is process.
We plan and do our production based in market demand; sales team are working on how to improve sales so that we can be able to utilize branch capacity

·       In the prior audit dated 8th March 2024, it was noted that.

ü  Average yield was at 191.12 loaves per bag,

ü  Utto consumption was at 100%,

ü  Average production was at 64.39 bags per day representing 79.49% of the set target of 81 bags.

No cases of remixes were noted.
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Production efficiency was evaluated for a period of 42 days from 1 March 2025-11 April 2025 with the objective of determining whether the hired production workers were meeting the set efficiency target of 4.5 bags.

·       The analysis showed that the actual production efficiency was 4.52 bags per worker, which was Above the KPI.

·       A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Table 6:Packing efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The branch management to maintain the production efficiency and improve further.
attributes.effect: ·       The branch management to maintain the production efficiency and improve further.

value: We will maintain and improve further.
We will maintain.
·       In the prior audit Dated 8th March 2025 it was noted that;Production efficiency was 4.45 Bags per production worker,5 extra workers were hired with a cost
Current

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings;

·       Packing efficiency for a period of 42 days from 1 March 2025-11 April 2025 was done to determine if packers were achieving their set KPI of 97 crates per packer.

·       It was noted that packing efficiency stood at 90.83 crates per packer which was below the standard of 97 crates ,26 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.23,712 as illustrated in the table below:

Table 7:Packing efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: ·       Management should optimize the allocation of human resources in the packing area by adjusting the number of hired packers to match actual production needs, thereby reducing unnecessary labour costs.Management should explore ways to streamline the slicing process for bread quarters to minimize effects on overall packing efficiency.
attributes.effect: ·       Packers did not achieve their KPI meaning the company incurred extra cost of Kshs 23,712 for hiring extra packers.Inefficiencies in packing operations can impact overall production flow and delay order fulfilment.

value: We are keen to improve despite challenges there are schools that require bread to be sliced in 4 blocks and 7 Blocks hence this is done manually and this affects efficiency.
This was mainly affected by slicer machine breakdown, and we are forced to slice schools orders manually.
In the prior audit dated 8th March 2025, audit revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 89 crates per slicer.
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was conducted at the mini shop on 11 April 2025, to assess whether operations were being carried out in line with the established standards.

·       The bread balance at the mini shop was subtracted from the total loadings for the day to determine the daily sales, and to establish whether the expected sales figure aligned with the confirmed amount recorded in the Mpesa till.

·       The audit findings confirmed that mini shop operations complied with set standards, however there were customer who had paid an advance payment and one customer for Kabata mini shop who paid Via k

·       The table below illustrates the findings.

Table 8:Mini shop Summary.
attributes.recommendation: The current controls in the mini shop are working effectively and should be sustained, with improvements implemented where necessary.
attributes.effect: The accurate reconciliation of sales and stock transfers at the mini shop indicates that controls over daily sales transactions are effective.

value: Variation is minimal but we will recover.
To maintain mini shop controls.
In the prior audit, the findings revealed there was an excess amount at the Mini shop amounting to Kshs +6.6.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       Generator fuel consumption was done for a period of 31 days from 1 March 2025-31 March 2025 to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

·       It was noted that generator fuel consumption was at 24.65 L/H which was within the range as detailed below:

Table 9:Generator fuel consumption.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should uphold the existing controls.
attributes.effect: The fuel consumption was within range.

value: Generator fuel consumptions are within range.
It is well managed in compliance with fleet controller
In the prior audit dated 8th March 2025, the findings revealed that the generator fuel consumption rate stood at 28.24 per hour which was vary with system which had 22.78L/H.

attributes.title: Mileage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of fuel consumption for the period of March 2025 was done to determine if fuel allocation was done as per the standard rates and Kilo metres covered.

·       It was noted Fuel Consumption was within range except KDB 367 Z for kabata route consumed extra 10 litres and KCM 627Q consumed extra 5 litres as detailed below in Appendix 1.
attributes.recommendation: Branch to always ensure fuel allocation is done as per Vehicle standard consumption rate.
attributes.effect: Vehicles that consumed extra fuel implies that extra cost was incurred by the company.

value:
·       I will do a follow up to check on kabata route fuel allocated and excess fuel will be recovered.

·       Others we will maintain.
I will follow-up the issue closely with manager and sales rep to identify the excess consumption if we get any then we will recover from concerned driver.
In the prior audit dated 8th March 2025, it was noted that fuel consumption was within range, however Tuktuk KTWC874 X which had no fuel records had mechanical issues.
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balance as of 12 April 2025 was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       A significant debtors balances was noted as of 12th April 2025 of Kshs 1,067,461.09 which should be followed for clearance, those that were due to institution was totalling to kshs 787,765.10, those of dormant customers were totalling to Kshs 25,668.8, others due to customers as detailed below in Appendix II.
attributes.recommendation: Sales representative is encouraged to actively follow up on overdue balances, particularly unsecured debts, to prevent them from becoming bad debt.
attributes.effect: If unsecured balances remain unpaid, they could negatively impact liquidity and operational efficiency.

value: ·       For dormant customers it is in process of recovery from security deposits. Sales rep and Territory sales manager is doing a follow up for debts recovery.
For dormant customers it is in process of recovery from security deposits. Sales rep and Territory sales manager is doing a follow up for debts recovery.
In a previous audit dating 8th March 2025, the outstanding debt exclusive of prepayments was KES 616,987.25.
Current
